content:
DataProtector Class

In this Article

Provides the base class for data protectors.

Syntax

Declaration

public abstract class DataProtector

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • System.Object
  • DataProtector

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
,
Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetHashCode()
,
GetType()
,
MemberwiseClone()
,
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
,
ToString()

Remarks

This class protects stored data from viewing and tampering. The access to the protected data is obtained by creating an instance of this class and using the exact purpose strings that were used to protect the data. The caller does not need a key to either protect or unprotect the data. The key is provided by the encryption algorithm.

Derived classes must override the [ProviderProtect(Byte<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.ProviderProtect%2A> and Unprotect methods, which the DataProtector base class calls back into. They must also override the IsReprotectRequired method, which can always return true with a potential small loss of efficiency when applications refresh their database of stored cipher text. Derived classes should provide a constructor that calls the base class constructor, which sets the ApplicationName, SpecificPurposes, and PrimaryPurpose properties.

Constructors summary

DataProtector(String,String,String[])

Creates a new instance of the DataProtector class by using the provided application name, primary purpose, and specific purposes.

Properties summary

ApplicationName

Gets the name of the application.
PrependHashedPurposeToPlaintext

Specifies whether the hash is prepended to the text array before encryption.
PrimaryPurpose

Gets the primary purpose for the protected data.
SpecificPurposes

Gets the specific purposes for the protected data.

Methods summary

Create(String,String,String,String[])

Creates an instance of a data protector implementation by using the specified class name of the data protector, the application name, the primary purpose, and the specific purposes.
GetHashedPurpose()

Creates a hash of the property values specified by the constructor.
IsReprotectRequired(Byte[])

Determines if re-encryption is required for the specified encrypted data.
Protect(Byte[])

Protects the specified user data.
ProviderProtect(Byte[])

Specifies the delegate method in the derived class that the stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.Protect* method in the base class calls back into.
ProviderUnprotect(Byte[])

Specifies the delegate method in the derived class that the stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.Unprotect* method in the base class calls back into.
Unprotect(Byte[])

Unprotects the specified protected data.

Constructors

  • DataProtector(String,String,String[])

    Creates a new instance of the DataProtector class by using the provided application name, primary purpose, and specific purposes.

    protected DataProtector (string applicationName, string primaryPurpose, string[] specificPurposes);

    Parameters

    • applicationName
      String

      The name of the application.

    • primaryPurpose
      String

      The primary purpose for the protected data. See Remarks for additional important information.

    • specificPurposes
      String[]

      The specific purposes for the protected data. See Remarks for additional important information.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentException

      applicationName is an empty string or null.

      -or-

      primaryPurpose is an empty string or null.

      -or-

      specificPurposes contains an empty string or null.

    Remarks

    This constructor sets the ApplicationName, PrimaryPurpose, and SpecificPurposes properties. The combination of these three properties must uniquely identify the data you are protecting. If the data is not uniquely identified, you might inadvertently read the wrong data, or other data might be substituted for yours. Examples of primary and specific purpose pairs are â€œinvoiceâ€ and invoice number, â€œgift cardâ€ and gift card number, â€œpasswordâ€ and URL string.

Properties

  • ApplicationName

    Gets the name of the application.

    protected string ApplicationName { get; }

    Property Value

    • String

      The name of the application.

  • PrependHashedPurposeToPlaintext

    Specifies whether the hash is prepended to the text array before encryption.

    protected virtual bool PrependHashedPurposeToPlaintext { get; }

    Property Value

    • Boolean

      Always true.

    Remarks

    By default, it is assumed that derived classes will prepend the hash of the ApplicationName, PrimaryPurpose, and SpecificPurposes properties to the plain text before encryption, and will check and verify the hash during decryption. If a derived class wants to specify the prepended data on its own (for example as an optional entropy value), this property can be overridden and set to return false. If PrependHashedPurposeToPlaintext is false, Protect and Unprotect passes directly through to the ProviderProtect and ProviderUnprotect overrides without altering the byte array.

  • PrimaryPurpose

    Gets the primary purpose for the protected data.

    protected string PrimaryPurpose { get; }

    Property Value

    • String

      The primary purpose for the protected data.

  • SpecificPurposes

    Gets the specific purposes for the protected data.

    protected System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<string> SpecificPurposes { get; }

    Property Value

    • IEnumerable<String>

      A collection of the specific purposes for the protected data.

Methods

  • Create(String,String,String,String[])

    Creates an instance of a data protector implementation by using the specified class name of the data protector, the application name, the primary purpose, and the specific purposes.

    public static System.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector Create (string providerClass, string applicationName, string primaryPurpose, string[] specificPurposes);

    Parameters

    • providerClass
      String

      The class name for the data protector.

    • applicationName
      String

      The name of the application.

    • primaryPurpose
      String

      The primary purpose for the protected data.

    • specificPurposes
      String[]

      The specific purposes for the protected data.

    Returns

    • DataProtector

      A data protector implementation object.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentNullException

      providerClass is null.

  • GetHashedPurpose()

    Creates a hash of the property values specified by the constructor.

    protected virtual byte[] GetHashedPurpose ();

    Returns

    • Byte[]

      An array of bytes that contain the hash of the stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.ApplicationName*, stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.PrimaryPurpose*, and stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.SpecificPurposes* properties.

    Remarks

    GetHashedPurpose computes the hash of the application name and the full purpose. The full purpose is a concatenation of all the PrimaryPurpose and SpecificPurposes properties. Each of the three parts is prefaced with its length so the hash can be reversed.

    Example

    The following example shows how to use the GetHashedPurpose method to hash the purpose properties for use as extra entropy. It is part of a larger code example for the DataProtector class. 

            // To allow a service to hand out instances of a DataProtector we demand unrestricted DataProtectionPermission 
        // in the constructor, but Assert the permission when ProviderProtect is called.  This is similar to FileStream
        // where access is checked at time of creation, not time of use.
        [SecuritySafeCritical]
        [DataProtectionPermission(SecurityAction.Assert, ProtectData = true)]
        protected override byte[] ProviderProtect(byte[] userData)
        {
            // Delegate to ProtectedData
            return ProtectedData.Protect(userData, GetHashedPurpose(), Scope);
        }

        ' To allow a service to hand out instances of a DataProtector we demand unrestricted DataProtectionPermission 
    ' in the constructor, but Assert the permission when ProviderProtect is called.  This is similar to FileStream
    ' where access is checked at time of creation, not time of use.
    <SecuritySafeCritical(), DataProtectionPermission(SecurityAction.Assert, ProtectData:=True)> _
    Protected Overrides Function ProviderProtect(ByVal userData() As Byte) As Byte()
        ' Delegate to ProtectedData
        Return ProtectedData.Protect(userData, GetHashedPurpose(), Scope)

    End Function 'ProviderProtect
  • IsReprotectRequired(Byte[])

    Determines if re-encryption is required for the specified encrypted data.

    public abstract bool IsReprotectRequired (byte[] encryptedData);

    Parameters

    • encryptedData
      Byte[]

      The encrypted data to be evaluated.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if the data must be re-encrypted; otherwise, false.

  • Protect(Byte[])

    Protects the specified user data.

    public byte[] Protect (byte[] userData);

    Parameters

    • userData
      Byte[]

      The data to be protected.

    Returns

    • Byte[]

      A byte array that contains the encrypted data.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentNullException

      userData is null.

  • ProviderProtect(Byte[])

    Specifies the delegate method in the derived class that the stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.Protect* method in the base class calls back into.

    protected abstract byte[] ProviderProtect (byte[] userData);

    Parameters

    • userData
      Byte[]

      The data to be encrypted.

    Returns

    • Byte[]

      A byte array that contains the encrypted data.

    Example

    The following example shows an implementation of the ProviderProtect method. It is part of a larger code example for the DataProtector class. 

        ' To allow a service to hand out instances of a DataProtector we demand unrestricted DataProtectionPermission 
    ' in the constructor, but Assert the permission when ProviderProtect is called.  This is similar to FileStream
    ' where access is checked at time of creation, not time of use.
    <SecuritySafeCritical(), DataProtectionPermission(SecurityAction.Assert, ProtectData:=True)> _
    Protected Overrides Function ProviderProtect(ByVal userData() As Byte) As Byte()

        ' Delegate to ProtectedData
        ProtectedMemory.Protect(userData, Scope)
        Return userData

    End Function 'ProviderProtect

            // To allow a service to hand out instances of a DataProtector we demand unrestricted DataProtectionPermission 
        // in the constructor, but Assert the permission when ProviderProtect is called.  This is similar to FileStream
        // where access is checked at time of creation, not time of use.
        [SecuritySafeCritical]
        [DataProtectionPermission(SecurityAction.Assert, ProtectData = true)]
        protected override byte[] ProviderProtect(byte[] userData)
        {
            
            // Delegate to ProtectedData
            ProtectedMemory.Protect(userData, Scope);
            return userData;
        }
  • ProviderUnprotect(Byte[])

    Specifies the delegate method in the derived class that the stem.Security.Cryptography.DataProtector.Unprotect* method in the base class calls back into.

    protected abstract byte[] ProviderUnprotect (byte[] encryptedData);

    Parameters

    • encryptedData
      Byte[]

      The data to be unencrypted.

    Returns

    • Byte[]

      The unencrypted data..

    Example

    The following example shows an implementation of the ProviderUnprotect method. It is part of a larger code example for the DataProtector class. 

        ' To allow a service to hand out instances of a DataProtector we demand unrestricted DataProtectionPermission 
    ' in the constructor, but Assert the permission when ProviderUnprotect is called..  This is similar to FileStream
    ' where access is checked at time of creation, not time of use.
    <SecuritySafeCritical(), DataProtectionPermission(SecurityAction.Assert, UnprotectData:=True)> _
    Protected Overrides Function ProviderUnprotect(ByVal encryptedData() As Byte) As Byte()

        ProtectedMemory.Unprotect(encryptedData, Scope)
        Return encryptedData

    End Function 'ProviderUnprotect

            // To allow a service to hand out instances of a DataProtector we demand unrestricted DataProtectionPermission 
        // in the constructor, but Assert the permission when ProviderUnprotect is called..  This is similar to FileStream
        // where access is checked at time of creation, not time of use.
        [SecuritySafeCritical]
        [DataProtectionPermission(SecurityAction.Assert, UnprotectData = true)]
        protected override byte[] ProviderUnprotect(byte[] encryptedData)
        {

            ProtectedMemory.Unprotect(encryptedData,Scope);           
                return encryptedData;
        }
  • Unprotect(Byte[])

    Unprotects the specified protected data.

    public byte[] Unprotect (byte[] encryptedData);

    Parameters

    • encryptedData
      Byte[]

      The encrypted data to be unprotected.

    Returns

    • Byte[]

      A byte array that contains the plain-text data.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentNullException

      encryptedData is null.

    • CryptographicException

      encryptedData contained an invalid purpose.
